description:
Cystoisospora suis is a protozoan parasite that belongs to the phylum Apicomplexa. It is a causative agent of coccidiosis, a parasitic disease that primarily affects swine, particularly young piglets.

Cystoisospora suis is an obligate intracellular parasite, meaning it can only complete its life cycle and reproduce within the host cells. The parasite primarily infects the epithelial cells of the small intestine, leading to the development of intestinal lesions and clinical symptoms such as diarrhea, dehydration, and reduced growth in affected animals.

The life cycle of Cystoisospora suis involves the production of oocysts, which are the resistant, environmentally-resistant stage of the parasite. These oocysts are shed in the feces of infected animals and can contaminate the environment, leading to the infection of other susceptible hosts through the ingestion of contaminated feed, water, or soil.

Cystoisospora suis is an important veterinary pathogen, as it can cause significant economic losses in the swine industry due to its impact on animal health, welfare, and productivity. Proper management practices, such as strict hygiene, disinfection, and the use of effective anti-coccidial medications, are essential for the prevention and control of cystoisosporosis in swine production systems.
